title: 103_s479
content: The "Small Business Incentive Act of 1993" is cited in Section 1. Section 3(b) of the Securities Act of 1933 is amended to increase the exemption from "$5,000,000" to "$10,000,000". Additionally, Section 3 excludes certain securities from the definition of an investment company. Section 3(c) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include provisions regarding the classification of an issuer as an investment company for specific purposes related to the purchase and sale of securities issued by registered investment companies. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify an issuer as an investment company for specific purposes related to the purchase and sale of securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify an issuer as an investment company for specific purposes related to the purchase and sale of securities, with exceptions for securities owned exclusively by qualified purchasers. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to classify an issuer as an investment company for specific purposes related to the purchase and sale of securities, with exceptions for securities owned exclusively by qualified purchasers. SEC. 4 defines a qualified purchaser. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to define a "qualified purchaser" as a natural person owning at least $10,000,000 in non-affiliated securities or a person owning and investing at least $100,000,000 in securities on a discretionary basis. The Investment Company Act of 1940 defines a "qualified purchaser" as a person who owns and invests at least $100,000,000 in securities on a discretionary basis, not less than $10,000,000 in non-affiliated securities. The definition of a "qualified purchaser" under the Investment Company Act of 1940 includes factors such as financial sophistication, net worth, assets owned or managed, relationship with an issuer, and other criteria determined by the Commission. The Commission may determine factors for defining a "qualified purchaser" under the Investment Company Act of 1940 and adopt rules for persons specified in certain subparagraphs to protect investors and serve the public interest. SEC. 5 amends the definition of investment securities under the Investment Company Act of 1940 by excluding securities issued by majority-owned subsidiaries unless they are investment companies. SEC. 6 provides an exemption for economic, business, and industrial development companies. Section 6(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to include a new paragraph stating that companies not issuing redeemable securities and regulated by the state where they are organized are limited in their activities as per their organizational documents. The company's organizational documents limit its activities to promoting economic development in the state through financial or managerial assistance to businesses. The company's securities must be primarily held by individuals or entities with a significant presence in the state, and sales must be limited to accredited investors or other approved parties. The company's securities must be primarily held by individuals or entities with a significant presence in the state, and sales must be limited to accredited investors or other approved parties as defined by the Securities Act of 1933. The company is prohibited from purchasing securities issued by investment companies, except for certain exclusions. The company is prohibited from purchasing securities issued by investment companies, except for certain exclusions such as securities rated investment grade or issued by registered open-end investment companies meeting specific investment policies. The company can invest 65 percent of its assets in securities deemed comparable in quality to specified securities. Despite this exemption, the company must adhere to certain provisions applicable to registered investment companies. The exemption allows a company to operate like an investment company under certain conditions. The company must file a notification with the Commission to rely on this exemption. Once the requirements are met, the company can rely on the exemption by filing the necessary notification with the Commission. The exemption allows a company to operate like an investment company upon filing the required notification with the Commission. The exemption may be subject to additional terms determined by the Commission for the public interest or investor protection. SEC. 7 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 by changing the minimum amount for exemption to $10,000,000. SEC. 8 defines an eligible portfolio company. Section 2(a)(46)(C) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to set limits on total assets and capital for exemption, with the Commission having the authority to adjust these amounts. The Commission has the authority to adjust amounts to reflect changes in indices or indicators for small businesses. SEC. 9 amends the definition of a business development company under the Investment Company Act of 1940. It specifies that a business development company is not required to provide significant managerial assistance to certain types of companies. SEC. 10 addresses the acquisition of assets by business development companies. SEC. 10 amends the Investment Company Act of 1940 regarding the acquisition of assets by business development companies. It allows for the acquisition of assets from any person, subject to regulations set by the Commission. Section 61(a) of the Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change the asset coverage requirements for business development companies. The new requirement is 200 percent, but a company can have a coverage of 110 percent under certain conditions. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies. A company can have a coverage of 110 percent under specific conditions, including exceeding 120 percent of total income over expenses and having at least 50 percent of assets invested in securities. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to change asset coverage requirements for business development companies. A company can have a coverage of 110 percent under specific conditions, including having at least 50 percent of assets invested in securities described in section 55(a). It shall be unlawful for any business development. The Investment Company Act of 1940 is amended to allow business development companies to have a 110 percent asset coverage under certain conditions. It is prohibited for these companies to issue senior securities representing indebtedness without restrictions on dividends, distributions, or stock purchases. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows business development companies to have a 110 percent asset coverage for senior securities, with restrictions on dividends, distributions, and stock purchases. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment permits business development companies to maintain a 110 percent asset coverage for senior securities, with limitations on dividends, distributions, and stock purchases. It is prohibited for a business development company to issue senior securities representing stock without provisions to prevent dividend declarations. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment allows business development companies to have a 110 percent asset coverage for senior securities, with restrictions on dividends, distributions, and stock purchases. Business development companies are not allowed to issue senior securities without provisions to prevent dividend declarations. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment requires business development companies to maintain a 110 percent asset coverage for senior securities, with restrictions on dividends, distributions, and stock purchases. Business development companies must comply with regulations to prevent dividend declarations. The Investment Company Act of 1940 amendment mandates business development companies to maintain 110 percent asset coverage for senior securities, with restrictions on dividends, distributions, and stock purchases. Amendments include changes to paragraphs regarding securities and indebtedness. The amendment allows business development companies to issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities without accompanying securities. The amendment permits business development companies to issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities without the need for accompanying securities, subject to certain conditions and shareholder approval. The amendment allows business development companies to issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities with approval from the majority of directors or general partners, in the best interests of the company and its shareholders or partners. SEC. 12. FILING OF WRITTEN STATEMENTS. Amendment to the Investment Company Act of 1940 allows business development companies to issue warrants, options, or rights for voting securities with approval from directors or general partners.
